conversation.content: [hesitant] I know I shouldn't just show up here after all these years but Dad's, [breaking], clubs are still sitting in his garage and neither of us can decide what to do with them.

[defensive] Well, um, you were always his favorite anyway, so I mean, why don't you just, [bitter], take them all and pretend like, [shaking], I never existed, just like you've been doing for the past five years.

[sincere] That's not fair and you know it—I stayed away because you, [hurt], told me at Mom's funeral that seeing me was like, [trembling], watching Dad choose golf over family all over again and I couldn't, [voice cracking], bear to cause you more pain.

[softening] Every morning when I knead the dough I still hear his voice, [wistful], telling me that precision matters whether you're, [careful], fitting clubs or measuring flour, and now those clubs are all that's, [breaking], left of him.
[whispered] I miss him too.

The thing is, um, I actually kept his favorite putter hidden in, [protective], my apartment because I couldn't stand the thought of you, [vulnerable], taking everything that mattered to him. [sighs deeply]
[surprised] You kept his Scotty Cameron—the one he, [touched], won the club championship with three years running?
[gentle] Sometimes I hold it while the bread rises and pretend he's, [yearning], still here telling me stories about, [nostalgic], every scratch and dent on that old club head.
[emotional] Um, you know, he actually had me refit that putter six times because, well, he said it had to be, [tender], perfect for when he taught you to play, but, umm, you never wanted to learn.
He asked?
Every single Sunday for fifteen years he'd come into my shop and, [aching], practice his putting stroke while planning how to convince you to join us. [pause]

I thought, um, I mean, he only invited me out of obligation because, [struggling], you two had your whole golf thing and I was just the daughter who, [resigned], chose flour over fairways, you know, the one who disappointed him. [voice breaks]

[firm] He kept a photo of your first wedding cake in his golf bag next to, [proud], his scorecards and told everyone at the club that his daughter was, [beaming], an artist who could make flour sing the way, [loving], he made golf balls dance. [laughs softly]

[tearful] Maybe we could display some of his clubs here in the bakery alongside, [hopeful], Mom's old recipe cards and create a little memorial that, [thoughtful], honors both of them and everything they gave us. [sniffles]
[warm] Well, um, I could build custom mounts for them, and, umm, maybe teach you what each club meant to him, you know, tell you the, [tender], stories behind every grip he wore smooth with practice.
And maybe, um, well, I could finally learn to hold that putter properly while you, [vulnerable], try my sourdough starter that I named after Dad. [chuckles sadly]
[resolute] He would have loved knowing we're finally doing this, [hopeful], together.
[crying] God, I've missed having a brother who understands that grief tastes like, [raw], metal and flour and freshly cut grass all, [breaking], mixed together.

The shop feels empty without him asking me to check his, [heavy], stance one more time, and this bakery smells exactly like, [remembering], Mom's kitchen on Sunday mornings when we were kids before everything got so, [wistful], complicated between us all.
Let's go get his clubs and bring them, [determined], home where they belong, here with the, [peaceful], rest of our family's broken beautiful history. [exhales slowly]

scenario: A golf club fitter visits their estranged sibling's bakery after their father's funeral, attempting to reconcile over their shared inheritance of their father's golf memorabilia collection.
